Some notes on abelian categories, based on my study of Vakilâ€™s The Rising Sea.

Let \cdots \xrightarrow {}{A}\xrightarrow {f}{B}\xrightarrow {g}{C}\xrightarrow {}\cdots be a sequence in an abelian category \mathcal {A}. The term B is called complex when f;g=0, and exact when the kernel of g is isomorphic to the image of f, in other words \operatorname {ker}{g}=\operatorname {im}{f}.
An exact sequence in an abelian category is a sequence of maps whose interior terms are all exact. A complex sequence is one whose interior terms are all complex.

A short exact sequence in an abelian category \mathcal {A} is an exact sequence of the form \mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {A}}\xrightarrow { } A \xrightarrow {f} B \xrightarrow {g} C \xrightarrow { } \mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {A}} .
If a sequence \cdots \xrightarrow {}{A}\xrightarrow {f}{B}\xrightarrow {g}{C}\xrightarrow {}\cdots in an abelian category is exact at B, then it is complex.
By exactness at B we may assume \operatorname {ker}{g}=\operatorname {im}{f}; we must show that f;g=0. Based on our assumption, we see that f;g factors through the zero morphism as follows:
Any morphism factoring through zero must be zero.
A sequence \mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {A}}\xrightarrow {}A\xrightarrow {f}B in an abelian category \mathcal {A} is exact if and only if A\xrightarrow {f}B is a monomorphism.

Suppose that \mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {A}}\xrightarrow {}A\xrightarrow {f}B is exact, and fix X\xrightarrow {g,h}A such that g;f = h;f to check that g=h. Considering that \mathcal {A} is abelian, this is the same as to check that (g-h);f = 0 implies g-h=0. Using our assumption, we may factor g-h uniquely through the kernel of f as follows:
As \mathbf {0}_{\mathcal {A}}\xrightarrow {}A\xrightarrow {f}B is exact, the kernel of f is in fact the zero object. Therefore g-h=0 and thus g=h.
